>>15080771
MWI benefits from not having collapse, and collapse is an ad hoc addition that doesn't show up in the Schrodinger Equation in the first place.

Various "It From Bit," versions avoid reals being somehow computed by a universe that lacks the information capacity to compute continuous variables that require infinite information. These get around having eternal Platonic mathematical laws that somehow exist outside reality and which are unaffected by them. Embracing such Platonic laws is the orthodox, conservative position in physics, and often championed more by atheists (along with determinism), but ironically the idea was interjected into physics based on religious appeals to support versions of Christianity where God was a divine "clock maker."

QBism is the most consistent, and has none of the seeming contradictions of all the other interpretations, but does this by making quantum mechanics and all of science "about" the limits of what can be known by a rational observer. Nothing is definite, there is only observations and the rational bounds for predictions of future observations.

Bear in mind that the mathematics required to describe QM also isn't grounded though. So all projects are, in some way, free floating, resting on assumptions. Dialectical gets you out of incompleteness and undefinability (Tarski's) as a ground for logicialism at the cost of no real working formal system (halting advances in category theory are cool but not a system).

QBism is also neat in that it isn't affected by philosophical and cognitive science related arguments for idealism (pic related).

I think QBism and information theoretic approaches (maximum entropy) can work just as well with super determinism as with MWI, or even Absolute Idealism. It's ontologically neutral.

For example their schizo ravings about Elon musk mindcontrolling them with brainchips they cribbed from Deus Ex. While they exaggerate absurdly a valid and realistic concern is information interface utilities in phone RRS apps and social media. These platforms are immensely popular and are to a laughably minor extent regulated and audited by impartial sources. Laying down the precedent this decade will save us a lot of headache in the the future. Also it will force legislation governing intercorporate compatibility and functionality accountability. Currently our governments are behind the curve and more or less operate on a general basic consumer rights level. Money back, replacement product, sub 10 year support guarantees etc... That shit cannot fly when technological devices become as indispensable and irreplaceable as basic utilities and civil protection services. We're already seeing this to some degree with electronic currency exchanges on a consumer level and digital citizens services (in many countries, applying for licenses, permits, healthcare information and insurance is already overwhelmingly a self-serve digital process). These technologies are on the way to becoming protected and strictly legislated utilities - even when the service is provided by private companies. This is in many ways a disadvantage to the corporate providers. They have to expend more capital to fulfill requirements mandated by law. An analogue can be seen in the power grid suppliers. The emergency generators, safety measures, redundancy facilities and black start plants are an immense cost to these corporations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15071476

Sure, we learn stuff, but we don't know how much of the knowledge from these usually unique (and cost-intensive) single patient cases the new knowledge can be broadly applied, or even reproduced with the same setup, the same patient the same experimental protocols and the same researchers after a period of time has passed that has allowed new neural pathways and memories to reshape the brain structures. This is because the exceedingly small number of cases like this are almost universally studied not as part of an actual clinical trial, but as case-studies of patients with motor-function impairments or debilitating neurological disorders and invasive brain surgery and electrostimulation is the only effective and possible treatment option.
So not only are our sample size and test protocols shit. Our actual test cases are deviations from neurotypical people which means unreplicatable results.
And as if that wasn't enough to make you cry already, the surgical proficiency required to perform this kind of procedure are more rare than albino street urchins in Liberia, and just because that's not enough: This magic suicide-compulsion implanter of a research field requires facilities, equipment, permits and funding that any non-corporate research lab have never been nearer to being allotted than at least 2 orders of magnitude.

So, let's understate the obvious and say it's not something that'll hit the shelves before next black Friday. And when it does, it'll be a gimmicky piece of shit that makes Google glass look intuitive and elegant by comparison.

I'm getting fatigued is thinking of all this. Good thing I'm just a dumb lab-jockey.

Ah, no no no, you misunderstand Anon. I'm not suggesting actually transmitting the actual feeling itself, or even more dystopic; imposing it on another human. Though, that would certainly be an incredible accomplishment from scientific perspective I strongly believe that the only truly unassailable and inviolable freedom that all humans possess is the freedom of thought. Putting it the way you do is to me an even more demented version of teaching a child love and physical intimacy by savagely molesting and abusing it.

What I'm talking about, purely conveying information is no more invasive or mind altering than reading a poem or touching sandpaper. The challenge is actually -defining- the language of this method of communication.
It's a circular problem in nature. You need to have a way to convey some kind of information in order to convey a shared language in the first place.
Which is why thoughts and emotions have been out of the scope so far. Conveying the meanings of a verbal language is aided by gestures and examples. Say sound ->point to green object ->repeat sound ->point towards a second object that only share the characteristics of being green.

As you mention early versions of a chip like this would be limited to very basic electric signalling No. What the starting point would be is analogues to something like Euclid's elements. We need a baseline. Our point in space and definition of a line. Like Euclid's work it'll probably only be a simplified definition but it'll work for now.
I think the emotions that are best suited as our reference points are the most ingrained primal ones we have. Stuff that has been an integral part of our biology since the first nerve cell existed. Hunger? Pain? Aversion? Pleasure? A sleeping state and a wakeful state? I'm not sure. Opposite ends of the spectrum would be best of course.

posts.com:
>>15081922
No. Set [math] u = y'[/math], then the equation is of the form [math] u'' - u = e^{-t} \sin(t) [/math]. Then, writing [math] u = u_n + u_s [/math] where [math] u_n'' -u_n =0 [/math] gives [math] u_n = C_1 \cos(t) + C_2 \sin (t) [/math] so that we can assign [math] u_1 = \cos(t) [/math] and [math] u_2 = \sin(t) [/math]. Then the method of variation of parameters is different from the method of undefined coefficients.
>>15081972
Next, we need to find [math] u_s [/math]. So we suppose it's of the form [math] u_s = u_1(t) f_1(t) + u_2(t) f_2(t) [/math] and we look for [math] f_1, f_2 [/math] such that [math] u_s'' - u_s = e^{-t} \sin(t) [/math]. We get some nice formula from the derivation which should be in your textbook for [math] f_1(t) = - u_1 \int \frac{u_2 g(t) }{W(u_1,u_2) } dt [/math] [math] f_2(t) = u_2 \int \frac{u_1 g(t) }{W(u_1,u_2) } dt [/math]. In this case [math] g(t) [/math] is the source term or [math] A u'' + b u' + C u = g(t) [/math], in this case it's [math] g(t) = e^{-t} \sin(t) [/math].

Next, write down [math] y' = u_n + u_s [/math] and integrate to solve for [math] y [/math].

>>15065994
Emailing profs is for anglo universities as far as I know. European institutions usually advertise their PhD projects on their websites. You apply via the website and send a cover letter, transcripts and other documents. The only exception to this is Switzerland I think. I know for EPFL, you apply to the program first, and then if they accept you, you have a year to find an advisor. That's when you start emailing. ETH also sometimes asks for applications to programs as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15066850
Exactly as you said. Basically tell them
1. Who you are.
2. That you want to work with them.
2. Very briefly, why you are interested
3. What draws you to their work
4. Here's why I think I would be a good fit. CV attached.

The key is getting noticed. If you have an introduction you should use it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15067611
>Also, does anyone have experience with online course certificates?
Unless your university offers credit for online courses taken at specific sites or offered by specific institutions, they're worth just as much as reading a book about a subject or watching a tutorial video series on YouTube made by Pajeetra Smellyeeth, which is to say, they can be used for the sake of casually dropping the fact that you've got some level of acquaintance with the subject, but might have absolutely no validity as far as academic credentials go.
If you're majoring in Applied Math, you'll most likely come across the same subjects you'd get a brief, somewhat shallow overview of in Discrete Math, like symbolic logic, set theory, graph theory, and combinatorics. Bear in mind that, regardless of what you major in, you will always have to work for somebody or make something for somebody else (be it a research institution, a non-specialized customer, or employees from a large corporation), so you'll inevitably have to deal with the human interactions factor. I hate it too, and would much rather do my own thing for myself, but it's what we all gotta do. Professors have to both write papers for academic journals and prepare classes for their students. People who work on mathematical models have to come up with presentations and explanations for the use of various mathematical functions that are used to model a certain type of phenomenon (be it physical, hypothetical, economic, etc.). People who make software have to code stuff with a broad end-user category in mind.
If you'd rather get an applied math major right now, and would honestly not mind having to do self-training for either heading into the engineering or software development worlds, then it wouldn't necessarily be the worst decision in the world. It's not really that hard to teach yourself how to develop software programs once you've got some strong bases in procedural logic. No clue about finance though.

>there's really not much information for guys wanting to go into finance or software development.
Many go via management consulting, which is covered, others go via an MBA, and that is not covered so far. Physicists should never have a problem getting software development jobs, it is more a question if you really, really want to.
>>Better then to aim for a niche where you can benefit from your degree

Things like interfacing or embedded work, where your software interfaces to hardware and real world events. Even just understanding if reading make sense takes a little insight where a physicist will have an edge. >>15065994
> Could you offer some advice on when to start applying for phds in europe?

In your own native country it will always be an easier process. Getting housing and so on will be rather tough, west European housing market is expensive. You can probably bear with eastern European prices since its a lot cheaper than US.

> which I will do with the research institute I currently work with, they want me to PhD there but honestly Id much rather do it in a university

Best advice I can give is to keep sticking with the research institute. Because if you're in university you still need institutions or companies that will give you data, work and support during your project. Otherwise it can be a lot more difficult to produce something that is good and / or in a timely manner.

> Do I need to wait until I've defended my master's thesis and properly have my degree or can I start sooner?

Start building contacts and network right now if you really want to move. Waiting to have your shiny degree (and possibly a publication) might seem like the attractive thing to do, but this can result in a period where you are establishing contact, getting judged, getting rejected and so on that could have been avoided.

> Any help and/or general guidance from anons in europe would ve very appreciated.

Such as? An important detail to know is that phd's are paid in Europe. Not much though. Typically between 2200-2800 euro a month in Germany I believe. This can be a lot higher if you're doing a phd for a research institute though.

They might be better paid for more of the same. I'd say algorithm knowledge is a pretty low priority for most data science / ML jobs that I've seen. Knowing stuff like SQL, SAS, data architecture, data manipulation, some cloud stuff, knowing a thing or two about devops / mlops, dashboarding, knowing how to talk to managers and IT to get stuff done is all more important and way more time consuming.

Likely in the interviews they will hammer on algorithm knowledge... even though you spend likely less than 1 month on that of the 12 months you work in a year.

>>15080009
To put it simply, if you had an infinite number of $1 bills and an infinite number of $20 bills, the $20 bills would be worth a lot more than the $1 bills. This is because the $20 bills have a higher face value, which means that each individual bill is worth more than each individual $1 bill. Even though both quantities are infinite, the $20 bills would still be worth more because they are worth more individually.

For example, if you had an infinite number of $1 bills, you could exchange them for an infinite number of goods or services that cost $1 each. However, if you had an infinite number of $20 bills, you could exchange them for an infinite number of goods or services that cost $20 each, or for a greater number of goods or services that cost less than $20 each.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15080746
Yes, both an infinite number of $1 bills and an infinite number of $20 bills are infinite quantities. However, the value of an infinite number of $1 bills would be lower than the value of an infinite number of $20 bills because the individual bills in the latter group are worth more.

To understand this, it can be helpful to think about the value of a finite number of $1 bills and a finite number of $20 bills. For example, if you had 10 $1 bills, they would be worth a total of $10. If you had 10 $20 bills, they would be worth a total of $200. Even though both quantities are equal (10), the $20 bills are worth more because they have a higher face value.

When we extend this idea to infinite quantities, we can see that an infinite number of $20 bills would have a much greater value than an infinite number of $1 bills, even though both quantities are infinite. It's important to remember that the value of any quantity of money is determined by both the face value of the individual bills or coins and the total number of them.

That’s an assignment expression, not an equivalence expression. x = x + 1 isn’t saying that x is equal to x + 1, it’s updating the value stored in the x variable to the original value incremented by one.

posts.com:
lots of computer scientists work on fundamental purely mathematical and logical topics. theoretical computer science is generally divided into two "tracks"
track B: lambda calculus, automata theory (very algebraic these days), type theory, denotational semantics, finite model theory (and descriptive complexity), certain areas of quantum information (like categorical quantum mechanics)
track A: "classical" computational complexity theory, computational game theory, cryptography theory, other areas of quantum information (like quantum hamiltonian complexity, for instance)
track B, sometimes referred to as "eurotheory" due to it being generally more popular in europe and the UK, is more logical and algebraic. on the other hand, track A is more combinatorial in nature. theoretical computer science is science (specifically, mathematics). software engineering is the application of this stuff. one could say software engineering to computer science is what engineering is to mathematical physics.
also, computation in general is becoming a rather effective and profound language for not just natural science but also linguistics, musicology, and many other disciplines. while mathematics is itself a powerful language for natural sciences already, it is mostly effective for modelling static (platonic, if you will) structures. computation, on the other hand, provides the perfect language for *processes*. the objects of study in theoretical computer science are intensional in nature, whereas ordinary pure mathematics is fundamentally extensional.
also, developments in theoretical computer science have recently been very influential towards the foundations of mathematics, which actually makes sense considering our understanding of computation is rooted in the foundations of mathematical logic

John Locke defined abstraction in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding:

'So words are used to stand as outward marks of our internal ideas, which are taken from particular things; but if every particular idea that we take in had its own special name, there would be no end to names. To prevent this, the mind makes particular ideas received from particular things become general; which it does by considering them as they are in the mind—mental appearances—separate from all other existences, and from the circumstances of real existence, such as time, place, and so on. This procedure is called abstraction. In it, an idea taken from a particular thing becomes a general representative of all of the same kind, and its name becomes a general name that is applicable to any existing thing that fits that abstract idea.' (2.11.9)

>>15081598
I'm going to go out on a limb here and say a bunch of Chinamen sending beeps and boops to each other on radios is NOT a brain.

The argument that it is seems to be:
A. Information is substrate independent.
B. Consciousness is somehow the product of computation and information processing.
C. This, because information is substrate independent and exhibits isomorphism, consciousness must be too.

This is a gigantic leap, even if you're willing to take other gigantic leaps to fully embrace physicalism as an ontology.

Embracing physicalism as a philosophy of mind simply entails that brains and bodies interacting with the enviornment generate consciousness. It does not entail that consciousness is substrate independent or reduceable to certain patterns of information and computation.

And indeed, it's hard to see how computation and information generated consciousness. Appeals are made to complexity and information because these terms are incredibly poorly defined and ambiguous. Somehow, being very complex and involving information results in consciousness. But how?

Boyle's Law is an emergent property that results from a very complex system. A large volume of gas has a very high entropy, it contains plenty of information. But do we think volumes of gas are conscious?

Invoking the concept of information at all can be begging to question, in that definitions of information in biology often include a reference to intentionality and an interpreter (e.g., Deacon's work). To the extent that complexity is often defined using the term information, this explanation is often doubly circular. However, if you take the physics view of information that doesn't require an interpreter, then you have the problem of explaining why volumes of gas that have plenty of information and complexity aren't conscious.

I like Dennett's multiple drafts model and appreciate his books, but his "solution" to the hard problem is just hand waving.

What counts is the swept area, NOT the blade area.
The blade shape is a compromise of length and strength. Longer blades increase swet area and power generated, while also increases bending moment near the hub. And at the same time the blades must handle te turbulent wind near the ground.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15080852
We already have a fair idea where the losses are.
With 160 m long blades, the circumference is close to 1 km. Thus the rotor must take more than 3 seconds to stay below the sound barrier. That makes for too low RM for the generator, so you need gearing. To save weight they use a planetary gear, but that has at best 3 percent power loss. So a modern 15 MW turbine loses about 500 kW in the gear alone and that needs actve oil cooling and that takes even more power. In case of power failure you need an UPS to keep the oil cold until the main rotor winds down. If any of this fails, the heat will quickly pass the flash point and you have an uncontrollable fire in the nacelle.

The the generator needs cooling. Just a 1 percent loss in conversion mechanical to electrical power is 150 kW. So add more active cooling hear. Bearings are plentifu, need lubrication, and an oil circuit with filter and cooling.

You also have a yaw motor and often motors for regulating the pitch of the blades. This requires a computer control system that needs power.

Last but not least, you need a transformer to transform up to line power, with frequency controller. This is usually places at the base of the tower so you can afford heavier and more efficient equipment here say 1 percent loss, which is 150 kW. Add some cooling to this, and this reaches 200 kW quickly.

People underestimate the enormous complexities and therefore the losses incurred. A nacelle on a modern wind tornine is now in excess of 300 - three hundred - tons.

>Dayton Miller
>Ah yes and all the subsequent "not-quite-null" experiments others did after them?
People wasted a lot of time trying to reproduce Miller's claims, including Michelson. Miller claimed he had found a positive result at altitude on Mt Wilson, so experiments were done in Switzerland, by balloon, and elsewhere. Michelson also took his experiments to Mt Wilson. They all came back negative, no one could reproduce what Miller found. He then claimed it was heavy vacuum chambers that were dragging the aether, he worrying did his experiments in air. This claim was also refuted by an interferometer with one enclosed arm. Millers results were given a fair shake, and they didn't hold together. Multiple papers have also reanalysed his own data years later, and find no statistically significant result.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15079284
>Can someone please explain the experiment where they disproved free will?
They gave test subjects a button they could push, and used an EEG to measure brainwaves. Whenever a subject decided to push the button, his brainwaves would change a moment before (about 0.2s before) any apparent movement of the hands or mouth or anything. It seemed from these experiments that the decision to push or not to push was already “locked in” before the subject was aware of making any conscious decision. “No free will” is an interesting way of expressing it but it’s basically clickbait designed to make someone famous (it worked, which is why we’ve all heard of this experiment)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15079965
That's a very bizarre interpretation considering we know that the act of deciding something and the body's physical movements have a lag time between them. Reaction times are a well-studied thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15079970
yeah it’s clickbait for redditors. but it is interesting because the EEG readings also appeared to precede any conscious decisionmaking. so it seems like a contradiction if you believe the mind should be one big atomic thing that governs all other things going on in the body.

On the other hand if you are not a redditor then you can put a little thought into it and find that is pretty obviously not the case, e.g. as you’ve said reaction times like from a baseball catcher couldn’t possibly go through a conscious decisionmaking process. so experiments like this maybe get us a little closer to understanding whats really going on

>>15077207
The Law of the Conservation of Energy only holds for intervals of time. As in, on a short enough time scale, energy is not conserved. Example: electrons passing through barriers they don't have enough energy for.

The mechanical reason for this energy nonconservation is the hiesenberg uncertainty principle: the conjugate of energy is time. So this nonconservation phenomenon appsies to other conjugate pairs as well: momentum over short enough length scales, doppler and location, etc

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjugate_variables
